meanings.definition: Cheap or inferior goods or material
meanings.sent1: The store was filled with schlock, items that looked cheap and poorly made.
meanings.sent2: I wouldn't buy that schlock; it's not worth the money.
meanings.sent3: The party favors were such schlock that they made everyone laugh.
meanings.sent4: Her outfit was a mishmash of schlock, like a costume from a bad movie.
meanings.sent5: The room was cluttered with schlock, making it hard to find anything of value.

meanings.definition: Something of low quality or value
meanings.sent1: The toy was a piece of schlock, falling apart after just a few minutes of play.
meanings.sent2: Don't waste your money on that schlock; it won't last long.
meanings.sent3: The movie was so bad it became a cult favorite for its schlock factor.
meanings.sent4: His excuses were just schlock, not fooling anyone with their lack of sincerity.
meanings.sent5: The painting was dismissed as schlock by the critics, lacking any artistic merit.

meanings.definition: To sell or promote something of poor quality
meanings.sent1: The salesman tried to schlock off the old, damaged goods as brand new.
meanings.sent2: I don't want to schlock these products; they're not up to our standards.
meanings.sent3: He attempted to schlock the faulty electronics to unsuspecting customers.
meanings.sent4: The company's reputation suffered when they chose to schlock their subpar services.
meanings.sent5: She decided to schlock the knockoff handbags at a discount, hoping to make a quick sale.
